title: 104_hr3940
content:
The "Teenage Pregnancy Reduction Act of 1996" evaluates effective programs for preventing teenage pregnancy. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate programs aimed at preventing teenage pregnancy to determine their effectiveness and methods for replication in other locations. The evaluation may involve federal agencies and private organizations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate programs aimed at preventing teenage pregnancy. The evaluation will involve federal agencies and private organizations, including the National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy. The evaluation design will consider various geographic regions, socioeconomic and racial groups, and provide recommendations for future programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate programs to reduce teen pregnancy, using measures of effectiveness defined by the Secretary. Funds will be provided based on scientific peer review recommendations. The evaluation report must be submitted to Congress and the Secretary by December 1, 1999. The evaluation of programs to reduce teen pregnancy will be completed by December 1, 1999, with a report submitted to Congress and the Secretary. The findings will be disseminated to various entities, and $3,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 1997 to 1999 for this purpose. The National Clearinghouse on Prevention Programs is established. The National Clearinghouse on Teenage Pregnancy Prevention Programs will be established by the Secretary within 180 days after the evaluation. It will collect, maintain, and disseminate information on prevention programs, develop networks for sharing information. The National Clearinghouse on Teenage Pregnancy Prevention Programs will disseminate materials and information to various entities involved in prevention programs, public health services, and social work services to reduce teenage pregnancy rates. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out the section on teenage pregnancy prevention programs, including funding for fiscal years 2000 through 2003. SEC. 4. ONE-TIME INCENTIVE GRANTS FOR EFFECTIVE PREVENTION PROGRAMS.

The Secretary may make a one-time grant to effective prevention programs to assist with operating expenses. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2000 through 2003.

SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. Prevention programs under this Act encompass various approaches for teenage pregnancy prevention, including abstinence, family planning, academic support, mentoring, job training, counseling, and social events. Definitions for prevention programs are outlined in the Act. The Act defines a prevention program as a program for teenage pregnancy prevention and the Secretary as the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
